newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian bond bears win thin contest.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian bond bears win thin contest.

text.p: *Australian bonds drifted lower during a thin pre-Christmas session with sellers gaining the upper hand after Friday's easier trend in U.S. Treasuries.
*Moody's upgrade of WA and Victoria has no impact.
Australian bonds drifted lower during a thin pre-Christmas session with sellers gaining the upper hand after Friday's easier trend in U.S. Treasuries.
"There's no real reason for us to be down here. It's been a pretty poor performance, but there's nobody out there willing to trade and it's going to be quieter tomorrow," one trader said.

The U.S. market was off on Friday on profit-taking after sharp gains earlier in the week and amid some disappointment of a tighter policy stance eminating from the minutes of the November FOMC meeting.
With only November new motor registrations due out on Tuesday before the New Year, the local market continues to find itself dependent on moves in U.S. Treasuries.

But with Japan, another source of direction, closed, the Australian market was very much in holiday mode with only just below 2,000 lots recorded on the 10-year bond futures contract. A 10,000-contract day is usually seen as mediocre.
Meanwhile, Moody's Investors Services upgraded the domestic currency ratings of the Victorian state to AA1 from AA2 and Western Australia to AAA from AA1.
Traders said the upgrading of the two states had largely been discounted and had little impact on the market.
"On a busier day it might have caused some business, but it just wasn't going to happen today.
The thin local activity saw the market underperform the
dollar bloc. However, conversely the Canadian market
outperformed its dollar partners during an illiquid session on
Friday. N.Z. debt was little changed, underpinned by the launch
of a NZ$200 million Eurobond by the World Bank on Friday.
